class Trumpocalypse.EventsLoop(testevents=None)[source]¶

Note the pygame.time.wait(0) call. This reduces CPU usage from 100% to negligible! This is noted at this URL: https://www.gamedev.net/topic/518494-pygame-eating-up-my-cpu/#entry4368408 The author states: “Giving up any remainder of the timeslice is the key to lowering CPU usage, which is done by sleeping - or, in the case of PyGame, calling time.wait().”

Sample body text: menu.body = {
text: ‘Some Main Text’, font_size: 32, top: 40, height: 300

}

randomDate(start, end, prop)[source]¶
strTimeProp(start, end, format, prop)[source]¶

Get a time at a proportion of a range of two formatted times.

start and end should be strings specifying times formated in the given format (strftime-style), giving an interval [start, end]. prop specifies how a proportion of the interval to be taken after start. The returned time will be in the specified format.

class Trumpocalypse.Item(item_type=None)[source]¶
Example items:
There is a NewCar item in the inventory with e.g. 100 uses. There is a Food in the inventory with e.g. 10 uses.

Purchase and resale amounts: 1) Buy: Remaining Uses * Purchase Cost

E.g. Buy Food with 4 uses left and purchase cost=10. So 4 * 10 = $40.
  1. Sell: Remaining Uses * Resale Cost
    E.g. Sell Food with 4 uses left and resale cost=8. So 4 * 8 = $32.

Each purchase of an item just adds to the total remaining_uses.

Inventory quick display (right side bar).

How about... Any number of new cars will shows as “NewCar: 100” (for one car)

...or “NewCar: 200” (for two cars) ...or “NewCar: 300” (for three cars) ... and so on
One food with 100 uses shows as “Food: 100”
...or “Food: 200” (two purchases of food) ...or “Food: 300” (three purchases of food) ... and so on

Trumpocalypse.run_tests()[source]¶
Trumpocalypse.run_tests()[source]

This is where tests are run.

In the python shell run import Trumpocalypse.py. Then run Trumpocalypse.run_tests() to run this code.

Param:None.
Return type:Does not a return value.
Raises:None.
